articles.headline: The Regional War No One Wanted Is Here. How Wide Will It Get?
articles.snippet: With the U.S.-led attacks in Yemen, there is no longer a question of whether the Israel-Hamas war will escalate into a wider conflict. The question is whether it can be contained.
articles.abstract: With the U.S.-led attacks in Yemen, there is no longer a question of whether the Israel-Hamas war will escalate into a wider conflict. The question is whether it can be contained.
articles.lead_paragraph: From the outbreak of the Israeli-Hamas war nearly 100 days ago, President Biden and his aides have struggled to keep the war contained, fearful that a regional escalation could quickly draw in American forces.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger, David E. Sanger, Farnaz Fassihi and Ronen Bergman

articles.headline: The Story Ron DeSantis Does Not Tell Is His Own
articles.snippet: Ron DeSantis has made lots of changes to try to revamp his struggling campaign. But he rarely tries talking about himself.
articles.abstract: Ron DeSantis has made lots of changes to try to revamp his struggling campaign. But he rarely tries talking about himself.
articles.lead_paragraph: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida has a classic American dream story.

articles.headline: U.S. Strikes Against Houthis in Yemen for Second Day, as Conflict Escalates
articles.snippet: The military fired at a target in response to rising attacks on Red Sea shipping, which the Houthis linked to the war between Israel and Hamas.
articles.abstract: The military fired at a target in response to rising attacks on Red Sea shipping, which the Houthis linked to the war between Israel and Hamas.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United States carried out another strike against the Houthi militia in Yemen, the U.S. Central Command said on Friday night, bombing a radar facility as part of an effort to further degrade the Iran-backed group’s ability to attack ships transiting the Red Sea.
articles.byline: By Vivian Nereim, Helene Cooper and Thomas Fuller

articles.headline: In a Setback for Beijing, Taiwan Elects Lai Ching-te as President
articles.snippet: Taiwan’s vice president, whose party has emphasized the island’s sovereignty, defeated an opposition party that favors reviving engagement with China.
articles.abstract: Taiwan’s vice president, whose party has emphasized the island’s sovereignty, defeated an opposition party that favors reviving engagement with China.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Taiwanese politician Lai Ching-te has for years been reviled by China’s Communist Party as a dangerous foe who, by its account, could drag the two sides into a war by pressing for full independence for his island democracy. Right up to Saturday, when millions of Taiwanese voted for their next president, an official Beijing news outlet warned that Mr. Lai could take Taiwan “on a path of no return.”
articles.byline: By Chris Buckley, Amy Chang Chien, John Liu and Damien Cave

articles.headline: ‘A Lifelong Nightmare’: Seeking Justice in India’s Overwhelmed Courts
articles.snippet: With 50 million criminal and civil cases pending, it would take 300 years to clear the country’s judicial backlog.
articles.abstract: With 50 million criminal and civil cases pending, it would take 300 years to clear the country’s judicial backlog.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the armed men stormed into the village of lower-caste Indians, fanning out through its dirt lanes and flinging open the doors of its mud homes, Binod Paswan jumped into a grain silo and peered out in horror.
articles.byline: By Sameer Yasir and Elke Scholiers

articles.headline: Their Songs Were Stolen by Phantom Artists. They Couldn’t Get Them Back.
articles.snippet: Bad Dog, a group from D.C., was forced to take a crash course in streaming fraud, a shadowy realm that costs musicians $2 billion a year.
articles.abstract: Bad Dog, a group from D.C., was forced to take a crash course in streaming fraud, a shadowy realm that costs musicians $2 billion a year.
articles.lead_paragraph: The guys in Bad Dog, a folkie duo from Washington, D.C., weren’t hoping to get rich off the album they recorded this summer. David Post and Craig Blackwell have been devoted amateurs for decades, and they’re long past dreams of tours and limos. Mostly they wanted a CD to give away at a house party in December.

articles.headline: For Some Young People, a College Degree Is Not Worth the Debt
articles.snippet: Because of high costs, some high school graduates have opted to delay, drop out of or forgo attending college altogether to avoid student debt that could hang over them for decades.
articles.abstract: Because of high costs, some high school graduates have opted to delay, drop out of or forgo attending college altogether to avoid student debt that could hang over them for decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Alex, my elder child, who identifies as nonbinary, was ready to apply for college in 2022, I felt ill-equipped to help them navigate the process. I was raised in a low-income household and had been unprepared to figure out how to make my own college experience affordable.

articles.headline: On the Ballot in Iowa: Fear. Anxiety. Hopelessness.
articles.snippet: As Monday’s caucuses approach, voters casually throw around the prospect of World War III and civil unrest, anxious of divisions they fear are tearing the country apart.
articles.abstract: As Monday’s caucuses approach, voters casually throw around the prospect of World War III and civil unrest, anxious of divisions they fear are tearing the country apart.
articles.lead_paragraph: Presidential elections traditionally speak to future aspirations, offering a vision of a better tomorrow, the hope and change of Barack Obama or the compassionate conservatism of George W. Bush. Yet this year, even before a single vote has been cast, a far darker sentiment has taken hold.

articles.headline: A Few Words About Netflix’s Success: Vivid. Snappy. Tags.
articles.snippet: The descriptive tags that the streaming service runs near each title — like “slick” for the show “Suits” — have proved crucial to getting people to click play.
articles.abstract: The descriptive tags that the streaming service runs near each title — like “slick” for the show “Suits” — have proved crucial to getting people to click play.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Grey’s Anatomy” is “soapy” and “emotional.” “Emily in Paris” is “campy” and “quirky.” “Our Planet II” is “relaxing” and “captivating,” while “Gravity” is “suspenseful” and “visually striking.”

articles.headline: How College-Educated Republicans Learned to Love Trump Again
articles.snippet: Blue-collar white voters make up Donald Trump’s base. But his political resurgence has been fueled largely by Republicans from the other end of the socioeconomic scale.
articles.abstract: Blue-collar white voters make up Donald Trump’s base. But his political resurgence has been fueled largely by Republicans from the other end of the socioeconomic scale.
articles.lead_paragraph: Working-class voters delivered the Republican Party to Donald J. Trump. College-educated conservatives may ensure that he keeps it.

articles.headline: California Has Dealt a Blow to Renewable Energy, Some Businesses Say
articles.snippet: Some companies are leaving the state or reducing their presence there after California greatly reduced incentives for homeowners to install rooftop solar panels.
articles.abstract: Some companies are leaving the state or reducing their presence there after California greatly reduced incentives for homeowners to install rooftop solar panels.
articles.lead_paragraph: California has long championed renewable energy, but a change in the state’s policies last year has led to a sharp decline in the installation of residential rooftop solar in the state.

articles.headline: War or No War, Many Older Ukrainians Want to Stay Put
articles.snippet: The front line in Ukraine is largely peopled by the elderly these days. Some can’t afford to get out. Others say they won’t abandon their homes.
articles.abstract: The front line in Ukraine is largely peopled by the elderly these days. Some can’t afford to get out. Others say they won’t abandon their homes.
articles.lead_paragraph: They sit in ones and twos in half-destroyed homes. They shelter in musty basements marked in chalk with “people underground” — a message to whichever troops happen to be fighting that day. They venture out to visit cemeteries and reminisce about any time other than now.
articles.byline: By Lynsey Addario and Megan Specia

articles.headline: As War Enters 100th Day, Netanyahu Vows to Keep Fighting in Gaza
articles.snippet: The prime minister of Israel struck a defiant tone after hearings at The Hague, where Israel has been accused of genocide.
articles.abstract: The prime minister of Israel struck a defiant tone after hearings at The Hague, where Israel has been accused of genocide.
articles.lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel struck a defiant tone in marking 100 days of war against Hamas in Gaza, vowing to keep fighting despite growing uncertainty over the outcome, international alarm over the mounting loss of life in the enclave and fears of a broader regional conflagration.
articles.byline: By Isabel Kershner and Adam Rasgon

articles.headline: Democrats Fret That Biden’s Power Players Are Not at His Campaign Base
articles.snippet: President Biden has a re-election campaign with two distinct centers of gravity — the White House and his Delaware headquarters — and advisers who are juggling two jobs at once.
articles.abstract: President Biden has a re-election campaign with two distinct centers of gravity — the White House and his Delaware headquarters — and advisers who are juggling two jobs at once.
articles.lead_paragraph: With less than 10 months to go until the 2024 election, the nerve center of President Biden’s bid for a second term is stationed not at his campaign’s headquarters in Delaware but within feet of the Oval Office.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Katie Rogers

articles.headline: ‘Mean Girls’ Musical Triumphs at Box Office, With a TikTok Assist
articles.snippet: The musical rendition of the 2004 original took first place over the holiday weekend, after Paramount used TikTok to introduce young audiences to the cult classic.
articles.abstract: The musical rendition of the 2004 original took first place over the holiday weekend, after Paramount used TikTok to introduce young audiences to the cult classic.
articles.lead_paragraph: The theatrical box office this holiday weekend was awash in “Mean Girls,” and TikTok may have been at least partly responsible for its domination.

articles.headline: The Next Battle in Higher Ed May Strike at Its Soul: Scholarship
articles.snippet: Cases involving Stanford, Harvard and M.I.T. are fueling skepticism over the thoroughness of research — even from the academic world’s biggest stars.
articles.abstract: Cases involving Stanford, Harvard and M.I.T. are fueling skepticism over the thoroughness of research — even from the academic world’s biggest stars.
articles.lead_paragraph: Marc Tessier-Lavigne, president of Stanford, resigned in August after an investigation found serious flaws in studies he had supervised going back decades.

articles.headline: U.S. and Iran Battle Through Proxies, Warily Avoiding Each Other
articles.snippet: Iran wants to flex its muscles without directly taking on the U.S. or Israel, but that cautious strategy is subject to miscalculation on all sides.
articles.abstract: Iran wants to flex its muscles without directly taking on the U.S. or Israel, but that cautious strategy is subject to miscalculation on all sides.
articles.lead_paragraph: For all the fears of an outbreak of fighting in the Middle East that could draw the United States, Israel and Iran into direct combat, a curious feature of the conflict so far is the care taken — in both Tehran and Washington — to avoid putting their forces into direct contact.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger, Julian E. Barnes, Vivian Yee and Alissa J. Rubin

articles.headline: Flush With Investment, New U.S. Factories Face a Familiar Challenge
articles.snippet: Worries are growing in Washington that a flood of Chinese products could put new American investments in clean energy and high-tech factories at risk.
articles.abstract: Worries are growing in Washington that a flood of Chinese products could put new American investments in clean energy and high-tech factories at risk.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Biden administration has begun pumping more than $2 trillion into U.S. factories and infrastructure, investing huge sums to try to strengthen American industry and fight climate change.
articles.byline: By Ana Swanson and Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: The War Has Reined In Ukraine’s Oligarchs, at Least for Now
articles.snippet: Oligarchs have lost billions from the shelling of their factories, and the government has used its wartime powers to break their political influence.
articles.abstract: Oligarchs have lost billions from the shelling of their factories, and the government has used its wartime powers to break their political influence.
articles.lead_paragraph: For weeks, they fended off Russian assaults, holed up in a vast steel mill under barrages of missiles and mortars. And when the Ukrainian troops defending the Azovstal plant finally surrendered in May 2022, the mill had been reduced to rubble and twisted metal.

articles.headline: The Smoothie Stop-By: When a President Tries to Be a Regular Joe
articles.snippet: For a commander in chief, retail campaigning isn’t easy, what with the counterassault team that follows him everywhere. But President Biden is starting to hit the hustings on every Main Street he can find.
articles.abstract: For a commander in chief, retail campaigning isn’t easy, what with the counterassault team that follows him everywhere. But President Biden is starting to hit the hustings on every Main Street he can find.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was a quiet day in Emmaus, Pa. The only sound on Main Street was the idling engine of the sleek black truck that some call a rolling doomsday communications control center, which was parked outside the bike shop. The men with guns dressed all in black were perched on the roof using binoculars to scan the area for terrorists or other bad guys.
